page.title: 100°C to Fahrenheit (212°F) – Water Boiling Point Explained
page.description: Convert 100 degrees Celsius to Fahrenheit (212°F). Learn about water boiling point, oven temperature conversions, fever implications, and conversion formula.

item3.question: Is 100°C a fever temperature?
item3.answer: No, 100°C (212°F) is not a human body temperature. There's often confusion with 100°F (37.8°C), which is a slightly elevated body temperature. Normal body temperature is around 37°C. Exposure to 100°C temperatures would cause severe burns and is incompatible with human survival.

item4.question: What is 100°C in Kelvin?
item4.answer: 100°C equals 373.15 Kelvin (K). The conversion formula is K = °C + 273.15.

item5.question: How does altitude affect the boiling point of water?
item5.answer: Boiling point decreases with altitude due to lower pressure. At sea level, water boils at 100°C (212°F). At 3,000 meters, it boils at only 90°C (194°F). This requires adjustments for cooking and baking at high elevations.

item6.question: What is 100°F in Celsius?
item6.answer: 100°F equals 37.78°C. This is calculated using the formula: °C = (100 - 32) × 5/9.

boilingPointFeature.title: Water Boiling Point Reference
boilingPointFeature.description: 100°C (212°F) is the standard boiling point of water at sea level. This fundamental temperature reference is used worldwide in cooking, science, and industry.

cooking.title: Boiling & Food Preparation
cooking.description: At 100°C (212°F), this temperature is primarily used for boiling, poaching, blanching, and sterilization — not baking or roasting.
